<@UUQ2EQW21> That sounds similar to what the Atom block-type-decoration can do. One thing I've been looking for that no editor seems to be able to do currently is let me flexibly make changes within lines that transparently respond to editing; e.g.
- replace a number of characters by a visual entity (extra credit: of a different width) that can be moved past, selected and deleted as a single entity
- attach a visual entity to a (group of) characters and have it push the text to the side
- hide characters (tricky for deleting)

I'd be very interested in working with your editor if you make progress on this!

text: <@UNGNT3BKR> it’s not perfect, and the parsing is a nightmare because .js has so many edge cases, but it “kinda mostly” just works. Most of the annotations are css on top of the actual code, so you can edit away no problem. If annotations do get broken during editing—for example, if you completely delete a token and insert a new one the previously associated CSS is also deleted—they are usually correctly restored once the edited line of code is evaluated again. The inline visualizations can be deleted / skipped over with regular key/mouse gestures just like text, but currently don’t get copied to the clipboard. Curious if you looked a CodeMirror… I do think it handles many of the use cases you just listed.
